topic.title: Application Level Identifiers

body.p: There are a number of identifiers that are to be provided by the host application for use by DIGI-G5 SDK APIs. This section outlines what these identifiers are and how they are used. In all cases identifiers provided by the host application are expected to be unique in time and across subsystems. For example, the OTN channel identifiers do not overlap with ENET channel identifiers or any other subsystem channel identifier. The host channel identifiers are typically associated with a SERDES end point such as a SERDES port or Interlaken interface.

li.p: Device Identifier: This is a 32-bit integer representing the underlying G5 device. It is used for the first time when the device is brought out of reset as part of g5_api_device_init() and for all subsequent API calls. Since the DIGI-G5 Host API can control multiple underlying DIGI-G5 devices the application must provide a unique value that identifies the device on which the operation is to be executed. The scope of the identifier is from the time the device is brought out of reset by calling API g5_api_device_init(), until it is shutdown by calling API g5_api_device_uninit().

SERDES Port Identifier: This is a unique 32-bit identifier representing a SERDES port. It is required as part of g5_api_serdes_port_los_cfg() for the purpose of LOS pin configuration and to provision related functions that bind a channel identifier to a physical SERDES port. For example it is a required parameter to API g5_api_enet_prov() and g5_api_otn_prov().

Channel Identifier: This is a unique 32-bit numeric identifier provided by the application software that is associated with a resource on the device such as an OTN, ENET, ILKN channel resource. It is expected to be unique in time across the device. That is, it is unique across subsystems and any associated DIGI-G5 Host API will return an error if the identifier is used to represent another channel resource. The SW/FW reserves user defined channel ids in the range of 0xFFFFFFF0 to G5_MAX_INT as shown below.

body.p: All identifiers are verified by the SDK to be valid and correct depending on their use case for each operation. For example:

li.p: The device identifier is verified to be unused on all calls to g5_api_device_init(). It is verified to be valid and in use for all subsequent API calls.

Channel identifiers are verified to be unused for all provisioning related API calls and verified to exist for all subsequent calls in which they are used. Note that channel identifiers are required to be unique across subsystems and not just within a subsystem.

body.p: It is the responsibility of the application to store identifiers, associate them with network management system resources, and use them for all operations on a provisioned datapath.
